column21: I do not think mandatory password change every year is the best way to ensure security: https://www.ftc.gov/policy/advocacy-research/tech-at-ftc/2016/03/time-rethink-mandatory-password-changes

When a security feature makes it difficult or impossible to get work done, the "workaround" for that is less secure than going without the security feature. Example: An automatic sign-off that kicks in too quickly results in me sharing my password with a teaching assistant so they can log in. Better to extend the maximum time before automatic sign-off than have a policy that results in sharing of passwords.

column54: We need better technology in classrooms. Even at Whitman where I am a faculty. We have many courses where class discussions are a must. This is particularly problematic now that many faculty have been recording their lectures in Zoom (since Covid) or are allowing some online students to join virtually. column50:
I understand the need to maintain an accessible IT infrastructure including accessible web pages, documents, presentations, etc.  But, getting faculty onboard with creating accessible content is IMPOSSIBLE.  

Many can't be bothered with it, so that work flows "downhill" to their support staff which then flows further downhill to IT staff.  

For the betterment of our campus, faculty should be mandated to attend workshops annually on creating accessible documents.  Period.  I realize this has zero chance of becoming policy, but I need to state it here.

Also, the IT Procurement Process has to be better balanced regarding accessibility.  Again, I understand the need for making vendors create accessible applications and products, but too many times good products that would be huge time savers for staff become unobtainable due to an accessibility policy that's well intentioned, but overreaching.
column51: Compared to 10 years ago, many of the IT resources work great.  Remote access is a good example.  SURA served us well for years, but the Yubi key method with on-domain laptops is a nice improvement.I

column12: we need to have LEMP or some kind of IT staff be available to support research events, symposia, talks, etc. on Zoom (there is no support and it's a platform for so many research and teaching activities now, with guest scholars or etc.). We also need more access to zoom webinar licenses--and how to hunt some down for various needs. Our tech landscape is fragmented. LEMP is tied to teaching (and it seems upper administrative support for events, but rarely anyone else: they are a FANTASTIC but too-small team, that needs investment to more seamlessly support the research/teaching needs of today. Also, it's simply not true, as LEMP states, that "home colleges provide IT support for events on Zoom"--they cannot do so, they are stretched so thin, so can we grow capacity here?)
column14: Ease of use,Picture quality,Information Technology Services support for using/troubleshooting,Other
column15: it is cumbersome, non-intuitive and nobody I know as faculty uses it as a first-choice. Usually, we are on Teams b/c someone from Central has asked that it be so. Zoom is way more intuitive in terms of pedagogical/meeting structure options and maneuvering.
column21: the security training i attended was not that helpful: I can't see how more training sessions like that would be great, but i'm not against it
column45: Just because I am not a user of assistive tech (prior page), you should have asked me about any obstacles I face--which are MANY. Why on earth does MarComm acknowledge that our lockup on Qualtrics, used by hundreds daily on campus, does not meet contrast ratio standards--cant' things be fixed/created with accessibility/inclusion in mind for ALL, rather than having our under-staffed/over-stretched university community try to fix something after the fact?  Now, to the website: I can't ever seem to find what I need. I wish research was on the front page. News is siloed by college or tag silos "Humanities" or "STEM" that make no sense for interdisciplinary work. The search function/algorithm for our site is not good. It's a visual mess. Calendars can't be built to cross-function (even in units that all have wagtail CMS, rather than wordpress still). Try looking at Cornell's pages/sites--how they use beautiful visuals, good organizing principles, and meaty content, all in one. What CMS are they on? How might we learn from our neighbor how to better tell our story? (Also, see how they brand their Zoom with beautiful campus photos that are super appealing--how do they do it? Can't we have an amazing aerial shot of campus on our zoom? We lack the vision to brand ourselves/put ourselves out there when we are hosting 100s or 1000s of people from across the nation or globally at a zoom event....and we also lack any tech support for this stuff, to host it. Sigh).
column50: Everyone is stretched so thin: for folks who don't do this stuff regularly, every single time I need to amend a document, try to fix qualtrics, assess a powerpoint, review a PDF, etc. to be accessible, it takes HOURS and lots of consultation. It's not a good use of my time (NOT, meaning here, that accessible/inclusive format work is not good, but we need perhaps a central place to have things submitted/reviewed/fixed? IDK but it's onerous and usually I miss something). There's also no funding to support inclusive-format public programs--one HAS to have a documented request, and yet, the University would like to have CART (and possibly ASL) at university-wide events. There's a disconnect between stated principles/commitments and actual infrastructure and funding to do what's needed. Period.
column51: Lots of it works well, but could be BETTER. In other words, we have a great College IT team, but I know how hard they work. LEMP is great, but they get booked up and also stretched thin.  Shoudl there be more shared resources (whether zoom webinar licenses, IT staff, web development)--currently a lot is siloed by practice (teaching vs. research) or college/unit. Does this make sense, given resources? Also, pushing off supposedly key commitments, like accessible format materials and events, with no resources, is hollow.
column52: lack of IT support for holding events on Zoom/etc and also for inclusive-format materials (e.g., to hand out or project in a zoom meeting, or distribute to participants, etc.).

column8:
New "updates" to myslice have made it much worse, not better.  Migration of Travel + Expenditures center to myslice has been a complete disaster, and is costing SU millions of dollars in person-hours.  There is little acknowledgement or response to the magnitude of these problems at an administrative level.  The university senate should encourage that the administrators responsible for the recent "upgrades" to MySlice be asked to step down and be replaced.  This is the very first time that, as a faculty member, I have been polled on how these changes have affected my work.

I am tenure track and use the purchasing card system for my lab.  I should not be asked to deal with literally hours a week troubleshooting failures (actual bugs and server issues) with the new myslice system.

Response time is a major issue.  When there is a problem with myslice, someone from IT needs to respond *instantly*.  Otherwise, I after some time troubleshooting, I need to set the issue aside, and come back to it when I can next block out time.

Generally, the IT support at SU is very good.  AVHE is fantastic, CAS IT is fantastic.  The myslice team needs to be replaced.
column21: My responses are centered on the fact that I should not have to give the university permission to delete all data on my personal phone in order to be able to check email with a native android app.  This is an absurd policy.  Either give us a university phone, or allow us to download email data without having to give this permission.
column39: There are various extensions that allow synchronization between folders on OneDrive or GoogleDrive and content folders inside blackboard.  The university needs to support one of these.  Uploading presentations to blackboard is a timeconsuming extra step.

I tend to use Google more often than not, because I can get answers much faster than trying to use SU Systems. As a result, I have tech sites from several other universities bookmarked because they have tech related info that is easy to find on a variety of relevant topics. Usually in the form of a webpage with direct links. Also don't find the emails that helpful. They are too long, and there's really no way to identify topics in the email later. column8:
Downloading class rosters produces an HTML file with .xls extension. While desktop Excel application is able to digest this, this is not so for other spreadsheet applications (on mobile platforms)

Class rosters include pictures of 100 by 70 pixel size, no higher resolution seems available. It is difficult to recognize people from a 100x70 pixel photo.
column39: I'd like to see more systematic use of either Blackboard organizations or groups in Microsoft Teams for academic programs. Some departments try to maintain a mailing list for "current majors", "current minors" but this is a tedious task since students add and drop majors often. MySlice already has the information on everyone's current major(s), which could be used to populate, e.g., a Blackboard organization "Majors in Subject X". The person(s) directing the academic program would be leading such an organization.  (As an alternative, this could be implemented in Teams. But students access Blackboard more often than Teams.)
column51: Zoom, Teams, and Office 365 applications work very well. Blackboard and MySlice are more frustrating to use than those. Google Workspace (not "Google Suite" anymore) has fine capabilities but is underused at SU, likely because Office 365 does most of the same things.
column52:
As an undergraduate program director, I need to communicate with our majors on a regular basis. There is no analog of "classroster emails" for academic programs. On the graduate level it is feasible to manually update a mailing list when students are added or removed from the program. But such changes happen all the time on the undergraduate level, so manual updates become impractical in a large program.
Creating an *automatically populated* Blackboard organization for each academic program (or at a request of such a program) would be a solution.
column53: When students add a class after the first day of semester, there is no notification for the instructor. The students adding the class often need to be sent some announcement, or be added to some online platform used in the class (e.g. for homework). The current methods of discovery of such students are unreliable in a large class. If an email notification is unfeasible, the MySlice roster could contain a column with the date when the student added the class. Sorting by that column would help.
column54: Orange Success mid-semester surveys are time-consuming because of 100% manual input. A faculty member likely has a gradebook (a spreadsheet) which could be used to automatically mark some students as "low exam scores", "low homework scores", etc. But Orange Success requires all this information to be entered manually. Some form of spreadsheet/CSV upload, like we have in MySlice for grades, would be helpful.

column8: The integration of Peoplesoft into the Navigation bar on Myslice has created issues. It is very hard to find what is needed day to day and creates my day to day to be disrupted while searching for what I need. Yes, the favorites feature is helpful, but if it is something not saved, it is very difficult.

column7: Does not have the feel that other modern websites have in 2022
column21: Studies have shown that most security issues in recent years happen due to lack of training to protect phishing attacks. These attacks are successful only when the userbase is not properly trained on how to identify them.

column52: Supporting MySlice. I work in ITS and 90% of our work is supporting users having issues with MySlice. I receive much negative feedback about MySlice, and virtually no negative feedback about any other website or application. My suggestion is to migrate MySlice to a brand new website that has the smooth feel and look of other websites designed in 2022. More than any other University website, MySlice is the website most likely to make someone lose interest in the University out of frustration due to its clunky feel and continuous technical issues.

column52: Coordinating Google Drive with my colleagues is sometimes challenging. This is due to two things that I observe. One is that I already have my own personal Google Drive account, and it's awkward to not be able to properly share materials I've built outside of Syracuse University with those inside -- specifically in reassigning ownership of Docs and Sheets files. (If I create a document with my @gmail account, I cannot transfer ownership to even *MY* @syr account, let alone a colleague's.) The second thing is smaller, but the fact that we share things via Google Drive to @g.syr.edu and not @syr.edu creates confusion. Why do we need a second email address to log into Google? I now have logins for both @g.syr.edu and @syr.edu. When documents are shared to me (from both inside and outside the university), it's inconsistent which of these addresses are being used. And it makes managing files more complicated than it ought to be.

We have a second machine on which I can scan-to-USBstick OR photocopy, but I can't scan-to-email or print from my office. And we have a third machine that I can print to from my office, but I can't actually log into the printer to access my queued jobs or cancel dead jobs that were left over from a bad print effort previously. Not to mention all of these machines rely on specific toner situations that, when they run low, seem to take ages to get replaced or addressed.

column21:
As a member of the campus ITS community, I would not find value in security training, though do think it would be helpful for other members of my Division.

While I understand the value and need for security, there are several areas where it has felt like we are playing "catch-up" and have quickly implemented solutions without a full scope of impact. 
One main area of concern is the ability to automate using non-user based accounts. I hope we can look at more modern ways of granting server/system level access like implementing more role based permissioning and an option for service account functionality without having to grant full access to tools to assist with blast radius.
column45: I have work closely with the syracuse.edu Digital team. We know navigation and content is currently an issue with all SU properties and overhaul initiatives are currently underway to optimize.
column50:
I understand and overall support the need for an accessibility policy, though I find the policy to be very limiting and inconsistently applied.

The policy is another area where I feel something was implemented very hastily and the impact on not being able to obtain certain business tools solely due to not being accessible, causes more work for persons needing those tools because accessible tools may not exist, or may exist without the features that improve the optimization of jobs.

The policy also looks at tools in a very "black/white" way, meaning there is minimal to no gray allowed. Many times these tools would meet some minimal accessibility requirements that would satisfy most general accommodations needed by users within a unit, but are not an option based on the policy.
I think there needs to be an evaluation to apply varying levels of the accessibility policy based more on usage and size within a unit, especially non-academic ones where the need for accommodations is both more known and controllable.

WCAG is still a new concept for many web-based tools and our policy tries to apply too strict of a requirement at too broad of an application in attempt to account for every case of an accommodation.

Outside of procurement, there is minimal global enforcement of the policy, leaving many areas improperly accessible - meaning they might check a box in a checker, but do not actually meet accessibility standards. 

While the policy promotes accessibility, it does not promote true equity or universal design, which should be the standard.

It also does not account for accessibility of information across multiple channels (print, signage, digital signage, website) . In many areas, we are forcing accessible PDFs of printed documents that in many cases live as a web native entity or should be promoted as the accessible alternative for documents or printed materials. The experience to a person needing to rely on accommodations is actually worsened by the requirement of the policy to apply to every channel. A web/digital first channel would serve as an enhanced experience had there not been a requirement an accessible companion document.
column51: Overall, things are generally maintained well and work, but it feels we are behind many other higher ed peers and most corporate organizations. There are a lot of more modern ways of doing things and opportunities to stop manual process or remove roadblocks or speedbumps.
column52:
There is not a robust enough Enterprise Application unit in ITS. In 2022, it is expected by staff, (newer) faculty, and students that tools serve a variety of use cases within multiple units be integrated and maintained in a more central fashion.
Many times at SU, because agreements over distributed funding cannot be secured, tools are not implemented at a more enterprise scale. This forces each unit to find individualized solutions, even if solving the same problems, and creates user confusion and lack of cross integration as well as limited access to data when implemented in siloed areas.
column53:
Lack of central and modern big data practices and access.
Relying on manual SQL data pulls and emailed csv files for lists of information is both a very old method as well as a major security vulnerability.

There are many more modern ways of allowing more real-time access to data streams while increasing the security all while better controlling visibility and access.
column54:
Administrative units are "second-class" to academic ones. Rules/policies that are put in place to benefit Academic Units are typically applied to administrative units with much different needs.
There needs to be a more defined central Administrative and Academic business use applied to the management of ITS resources and policies.

column21:
Edge-Security: campus should adopt a Zero-Trust model. no reason to have computer ports being probed by external networks. why "invite" a compromise?
Infrastructure-Security: more resources are needed so that ITSSec has the bandwidth/manpower to stand-up a real SOC that can perform true network security. Why have a wide-spectrum of (security) postures when a uniform-posture ensures a true-baseline?

column53: Slate implementation.  Lack competent IT staff has delayed it's implementation and development.  The people doing most of the work and having the most knowledge aren't IT people.  Lack of IT resources has also caused the hiring of outside consultants.
column54: No other area to put this.  The biggest problem I see at SU, is the lack of an institutional oversite person or office for computing projects.  Any department wanting to implement new software into SU systems, needs to have a place to introduce their project, and have an idea of what other areas of the University that their project might affect.  Then any affected areas should be notified of the project and invited to meeting to let the lead area know of any issue that could pop up in their area by said project.  At Syracuse University, a constant problem is one hand not knowing what the other hand is doing.  Too many times, changes are made in one area, and it affects 3 (or so) other areas, and they have no idea.

column39:
First, let me say that I think ITS is great--always quick to respond and always very helpful whether I am in the classroom or just making a request outside of my teaching hours.  Love the staff!

BlackBoard is very clunky and old-school and makes more work for students and professors.  I don't understand why we haven't switched to Google Classroom yet--I visit high schools as part of my job and it seems so much more intuitive and less clunky.  For instance, why can't students upload "Pages" documents or google docs on BlackBoard that I can then grade 'in-line?' Why does it all have to be Word or pdf?  Now, too with the way that courses are visible in BB, it's difficult for me to organize the courses in the way that I want to see them. I liked being able to organize them myself in a way that felt useful for me.  Also, the in-line grading feature is very wonky at times, sometimes, I try to highlight two-three sentences I want to comment on and it will grab a whole page of text (for some reason) and then won't let me let go of any. It's very glitchy at times.
column51: The helpdesk!  I also like the emails from ITS with teaching tools, etc.
column52: AirOrangeX connectivity--not just for me (as I mentioned, it sometimes is glitchy) but very often nowadays, students have a lot of trouble connecting to wi-fi in class.  This problem just seemed to begin this year.

column21: The fact that faculty cannot be a full administrator of their main computer has always been a significant hassle for me. It has cost me many many hours of wasted time. I do not believe that there is a legitimate security-related reason for doing things this way, and that there are better alternatives, at least as an option for faculty who can handle administering their own computers effectively and efficiently. This has been a significant source of frustration for me the entire time I have been at SU.
column45: I think some of the department websites are quite poor. It is not always easy to find information, and in some cases sacrifices seem to have been made to conform to a standard template, or perhaps to make it easier for a non-specialist to set up the sites. The most recent transition to a new, consistent format seems to have lost a lot in the process. I realize that setting up and maintaining websites is very difficult, and that it isn't easy to find people with the skills to do this well.
column51: I have been impressed with classroom support the few times that I have had to call them. The responses have been quick, and they have solved problems.
column52: I am an inveterate tinkerer with my main computer. I install/uninstall software regularly. I keep software up-to-date with the most recent versions and security updates. I do this because I spend most of my day on my computer and I want it to function exactly the way I want it to. Not having adminstrative control over my computer is a constant source of frustration, as are the various changes that ITS makes to the computer, and the software and profiles they install. To put things bluntly, in the past 15 years, I have never had a computer that I purchased myself and that I had any problems with that I couldn't solve myself. In contrast, I have never had a computer that I purchased through ITS that I did not have problems with. Given that I spend much of my work day in front of a computer, this is a source of near constant frustration. And I believe the security-related justifications for this are misguided.
column53: Technical support though ITS is very slow. Perhaps the support team is understaffed, but this is not the impression that one gets when one visits the office in person. When faculty have a serious problem with a computer, it is usually a show-stopper, something that prevents them from doing their job. Too often, the solution is to drop off a laptop for a day or more. This is just not a workable situation. Problems need to be solved much more quickly. This is one reason I am very reluctant to go to ITS with any problems. It is another reason it would be very helpful to have full administrative access over my computer. In the worst-case scenario, I can wipe a computer clean and reinstall from a backup in less time then it takes ITS to figure something out.

column21: The use of computing resources has become more and more onerous over the past few years. For example, my office computer is locked down more and more, to the point where I can't even do simple updates (e.g. to R or Stata) anymore without asking someone from IT to come to my office and type in passwords. I used to be able to do that myself, but central IT has centralized and restricted it more and more. It's not clear to me how that improves security, all it does is make me spend more time getting things working. I'm at the point now where I often just bring my private laptop to the office.
column39: Blackboard is the worst thing about teaching at SU. It's sooo outdated and clunky. Even the simplest actions require dozens of clicks (just try getting a quiz from a past semester and deploy it in a current class without looking up the instructions). I can't for the life of me understand why we're not using Canvas or some other alternative, which are infinitely better and used by our peer institutions; and why we've apparently even extended our contract with Blackboard.
column52: Please allow faculty more leeway in setting up and updating their computer without centralizing and restricting everything.
column53: Please allow email aliases. Having to use our NetID is really annoying and unprofessional (they sound like early 2000s AIM usernames). For example, my email address is the first letter of my first name, the first letter of my middle name, and then the first 6 of the 7 letters of my last name. I can't tell you how often people have told me that they mistyped my email and their correspondence didn't reach me. And it just sounds unprofessional to have such a weird email address. Why not allow aliases like firstname.lastname? Email addresses can be longer than 8 characters!

Just to log into my email or do something basic I have to log in, receive the code, enter the code but then also verify on all my Microsoft and Google accounts it was me, so enter new sets of codes.

column51: They all work well enough.
column52:
Access Services at the libraries has made available approximately 15 laptops for two-week loans in order to support students whose computers have stopped working and need repairs. Over the past year it has gotten to the point where these ~15 laptops are not nearly enough to meet the demand, and we regularly hear from frustrated students - and occasionally their parents - that there is no other avenue for them in this situation. We have neither the financial resources nor the organizational capacity to expand our offering, and so it is also frustrating to us that no other solutions exist on campus for these students. We end up as a complaint center simply because we have attempted to create some sort of solution where nobody else has. This has been further complicated by a recent trend of Faculty requesting these machines for similar reasons and expecting that we not only prioritize their requests but also waive the fee that we charge for the service. My understanding is that individual colleges' ITS departments should have solutions for Faculty, but the Faculty seem entirely unaware.
This may not be the intended sounding board for this complaint, but I have seen no other. This is a significant issue that is impacting students on campus and it should be formally addressed.

column52: As a university member, I am forced to use my computer and phone in ways that I find counter productive. For example, the very limited approach to email where SU has essentially enabled Microsoft to dictate what is an acceptable email client is greatly frustrating. This is not an issue of my willingness to learn a new client. It takes a considerable amount of time and effort dealing with email each day; why am I forced to use a client that does not fit with my workflow, which I have spent years tweaking and optimizing? There are open standards that could be embraced. Please enable IMAP and/or POP support.
column53: Though many SAS services are much easier to deploy, I do not think the campus has serious confronted issues of security, privacy, or the relationships these imposes upon university members. Why is my work as a teacher contingent upon a relationship to Microsoft? I do not appreciate all the social media aspects that Microsoft grafts onto basic tasks such as email, file sharing, calendaring, video conferencing, etc. I further do not appreciate that they extract value from me (in the training of AI algorithms) while I have no way to opt out. Similarly, with Zoom, which runs facial recognition algorithms on video calls. (Microsoft is likely doing similar with Teams.) We have no idea the consequences for this in the near- or long-term future---both for Americans, but also for international faculty and students. I find it troubling that SU does not take these issues seriously. I would love it if the university embraced the hosting of more services on site and, even more so, if those services were opensource.
column54: Please, please do not force me to watch any inane videos as part of "training." These do not respect people as agents and are antithetical to the notion of education. Further, they have never been insightful.

column21: I believe forcing a new password every year is a hurtful practice. It forces people to come up with mundane or simple things. It is useful from people who are always at the same terminals and can have it saved. But for those of us who must be able to sign in to different computers all the time, we cannot use a really long random password such as the ones suggested by chrome and such. Long lines of random code work for some people but I would not be able to pull out paper and type in insane passwords. So, in most places that force such an annual change I would simply change a number or something, but here it denies "similar" PWs. Since I need to be able to log in to my terminal as fast as possible I stick to a variation of password that is already familiar. but I fear after a few more years/changes I will be forced to choose more and more simple passwords. I understand how a yearly change can help provide security, but in my case, it will lead to less security over time.

column52: This survey is a nice representation of the shift in ITS over the decades I've been here. 20 years ago, ITS had some vision about improving things--now, it's tons of 3rd party platforms (most of which are poorly designed and ill-fitting), security, accessibility -- all geared towards fixing problems. Not that those things aren't important, but they're reactive and aspire to functionality. But then, that's true of ed-tech in general, thanks to blights like Blackboard. Instead of making the institution better, they've helped to create an ongoing cycle of mediocrity that costs way more than it should and yields less than it did 20 years ago. It's not the fault of anyone in particular, but it's sad to see.

column4: This survey question is the first time I've thought about it in a while, which is a great sign -- apparently, it just works when I need it. I use it all the time and can't remember running into any kind of trouble recently.
column8:
The biggest issue is that my ability to access MySlice in various browsers with various settings has been inconsistent in the past few years. There have been times when I have to start a less secure browser in order to get it to load properly. My preferred browser uses a pretty strict selective script blocker, and so it is helpful to know precisely what domains I need to whitelist, and that becomes hard when the page has many layers of requests, each conditional on the last being successfully executed. Right now, though, it seems to work fine.
  
Separately (or perhaps related), the new layout with the large tiles is sort of annoying -- I used to be able to use my browser's text search function to quickly find the tools I needed, since they were all listed in plain text on a single web page. Now I have to either remember which section they are in or use MySlice's built-in search tool, which of course cannot possibly be as streamlined as a simple browser text search. That said, MySlice probably shouldn't be designed around the needs of someone like me who is highly tech-savvy -- I will be able to find what I need one way or another. Maybe the tiles make it easier for some people.
column15: The intrusiveness of the software itself. Zoom is lightweight and I can install it on my personal devices with ease. Teams is clunky and awkward to use. It attempts to impose a one-size-fits-all approach to integrating with other Microsoft software. It is a prime example of Microsoft's increasing efforts to force Windows users to adopt an always-online workstyle. Obviously Teams is on my work computer, but I will *never* install it on my personal devices to use at home.
column45: The way the site design handles departments (e.g., Psychology) nested within colleges (e.g., College of Arts and Sciences) is awkward. When I am quickly navigating Psychology pages, it is easy to confuse CAS-specific links and Psychology-specific links.

column21: My lab needs shared networked server space that is NOT in Microsoft cloud or Google docs. My students do not have managed computers. They should be able to log into networked server space with a password if they do not have managed computer. This is a constant pain for my lab and it makes absolutely no sense why we cannot figure out a way to make networked server access secure without resorting to a virtual machine or to these abysmal and unworkable cloud-based resources.
column45: The way that individual department webpages are set up with that invasive new SU banner at the top is very unintuitive. Getting to the main SU webpage should be a single small link at the top, not a whole banner that dominates the page.

column50: Accessibility is an important commitment, but I see two things that are a bit frustrating. The first is that there is a lot of inconsistency -- I've even attended talks on accessibility where the materials themselves were not accessible. The second is that we grossly underestimate the labor that goes into ensuring that course documents are accessible, especially when using readings and other materials in Blackboard. I somewhat wonder if having a central office or person to do these adjustments (such as .pdf corrections) would be useful, given that there is a great deal of nuance. I realize that's quite costly (and presumes faculty are planning enough in advance), but it's a struggle ... especially when so many of our "older" documents fail these checks but do not seem to be correctable (at least, in my skill set). That said, Syracuse Libraries is fantastic at assisting here, with respect to requests for new content.

column52: THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT: The television screens do not show a true color or contrast representation of visual materials. Some classroom TVs used for these reviews are horrible - making the details and features of the photos unrecognizable. I am constantly apologizing to students for the quality. It's embarassing.

Here, the RCM budget model kills efficiency - our "computing labs" are a joke; machines of different age and speed, most only for email. e.g. steps needed to include a sketch on the physical whiteboard on Blackboard: 
without any editing
1] take a picture with my personal smartphone
2] upload to cloud
3] download on SU computer
4] upload to blackboard
5] resize in Tiny rich text editor

column52: SU wants to have technically savvy institutional systems (that significantly enhance our student, faculty, and staff day-to-day experience!), services, and analytics with no budget for implementation and support ongoing. To implement institutional-wide systems such as MySlice, Slate, Blackboard, Tableau/DataInsights, with no funding/resources for the needed implementation of these, as well as ongoing support is crippling our IT staff and departments across campus. This is being done by asking them to learn and adopt technical skill sets that should be more central. This causes bad business processes, data silos, extended project timelines, and ultimately a bad customer experience

column21: This goes to my comment about the devs not considering other browsers, but I'm automatically logged into myslice after I log in at work, and I open MS edge.  On Firefox I have to log in. And that reminds me, why should I have to trick the browser if I want to log someone else into their myslice from my account?  It's ridiculous having to use a private window to log an employee in from my profile.

column21:
It's annoying that the two factor service you use doesn't have a hardware security key as an option.  I'd like to have additional verification options other than my phone in case it's dead or charging in another room or otherwise not on my person.  What do you do for faculty members that don't have cell phones?

Upon login, the Azure vpn service asks me if I want to give control of my personal device to the university, which will make my personal device subject to AD.  See this guide for a description of the issue and a possible solution: https://msendpointmgr.com/2021/03/11/are-you-tired-of-allow-my-organization-to-manage-my-device/.

Having a vpn client that's fully crossplatform (specifically, linux compatible) would be ideal but I can understand why that's not a high priority.  That said, cisco anyconnect is cross-platform and fairly commonly used.  Not sure how pricing/support compares though.
column39:
Coming from canvas, blackboard's interface seems counterintuitive in many ways.  I don't like that courses open an overlay over the screen with a large "x" in the corner, which I inevitably click thinking it will go back to the main screen of my course rather than going back to the list of courses.  Having a course as a page is a more sensible paradigm to me.

Aside from UI nitpicks like that, it seems like a fairly powerful platform, maybe moreso than canvas, so I can't be too critical of it I guess.
column45:
I like the answers service!  Much better than previous institutions that I've been at, which relied a great deal on individual staff-person's knowledge rather than a searchable knowledge base.  I'd focus information accessibility work on improving the quality of this service.

One constructive criticism is that articles could be written in a way that makes it more clear when a policy only pertains to a particular department/college/etc., or perhaps it the web page could be modified so that it's more evident to the reader that the scope of the article is limited to certain departments/colleges.
column50: The biggest issue is that LaTeX is absolutely essential to mathematicians for creating pdfs with mathematical content, but LaTeX currently does not support accessibility features very well.  It seems from my research that this is improving but perhaps not quickly enough.  Two of the links on the syracuse university answers page for math accessibility are dead, and one of them only addresses using mathjax as a solution which isn't relevant to pdf creation (at least, not in my current workflow, which mostly involves uploading pdfs to blackboard as files for students to view).
column51: My personal computer is working well!  Printing services work fine too.  Not really anything to complain about aside from the specific details that I discussed elsewhere, and whiteboard support (see below).
column52: Online pen-writing collaboration still isn't great, especially with folks from other institutions (i.e., my research collaborators).  Zoom whiteboards don't function very well in terms of quality of the writing experience or workflow of saving/organizing boards for later use.  I've tried sharing onenote documents but the latency is too high.  The best solution that I've found is to self-host a whiteboard server for a particular pen annotation app that I use ("write" by styluslabs), which I have to host from my personal computer at home since my remote collaborators can't connect to a computer internal to the syracuse network.  I'm not really sure what a good substitute for this would be, as I've been dissatisfied with all the various online whiteboard services (i.e. jamboard), again for the quality of their writing experience and their latency.  There might not be a good product available for this problem.

column4:
The campus wireless network is generally fairly stable. However, there are two issues:

1) There is no mechanism to get a non-managed computer on the wireless network without using a specific NetID/password. There are many reasons to use non-managed computers -- to run operating systems like Linux, and to have full local control over computers that need to run specialized software. Sometimes these machines need to be used in teaching spaces by a shared group of people (many students), and it is awkward to use a faculty member's personal SUID on a shared machine.

2) The instructions to get Linux systems on AirOrangeX are not clear.

column39:
The online teaching tools and technology (Blackboard, Kaltura) are so poor that I have been using alternatives (open websites to post course material, public streaming platforms for video during the pandemic). 

We should stop spending so much money on classroom technology. Provide a basic computer in each classroom (ideally running an open-source OS) connected to the A/V equipment, ditch Kaltura and PlayPosit and all this snake oil, and ditch Blackboard for something that is simpler and works better (and is probably cheaper). Ditch Zoom for Jitsi, even.

We are massively over-technologized -- and I'm a scientist specializing in computation saying thi
column45: Campus websites have too much javascript and too complex of a structure. The fact that department websites are now swallowed by the colleges makes this far worse. My home department wants to update our website to fix old/incorrect information and make the layout reasonable, but we cannot do so because the college has stolen it from us.
column50:
Microsoft Word and Adobe Acrobat are rarely used for document creation in many fields. LaTeX is the primary way to author documents. Currently, there *is* a need for greater LaTeX compatibility with screen readers.

f the university wants to facilitate greater accessibility, the best thing they could do would be to take some of the money used on snake oil and use it to sponsor one of the efforts to create a usable accessibility package for LaTeX. This would both help SU and everyone else around the world.

The biggest challenge facing me is that Blackboard is awful -- it is clunky and slow and has too many features. (There's no way to ctrl-F a student's name in a 600 person class, for instance -- this is not good design.)

Please replace Blackboard with something that works better. We can post materials for students on the open web or a google drive -- all we need a LMS for is telling Fred what their grades are without Susie seeing them.

column4: Most of the time, AirOrangeX works for me, but if I am assigned a classroom that does not have stable, easy access to the wifi, it is a nightmare. My class is based on internet interaction with my students even while being in-person. I use google docs, blackboard, and other online applications to do activities with my students. Their ability and my ability to access the wifi is crucial to the learning process. I have had issues in the past, but I have a class in life sciences this semester, and I have had to print out my google doc prompts every class because I cannot count on the wifi. Every single class, I have at least a few students who cannot access the internet and have to use these paper copies. Specifically, this makes it difficult for me to give real-time feedback and track my students' participation in class activities. Despite calling ITS (and I don't believe their troubleshooting was at fault), this issue never got resolved. They believe it has to do with hotspots, which I can talk to my class about, but if other classes are using hotspots, there is nothing I can do. Hence, I still have this issue in this particular class.

column21: I have taught at six institutions, and I have never seen a campus with so many security failures. Speaking with colleagues at other universities, they never experience the endless spam and phishing attacks that make it into our inboxes at Syracuse. Even worse was the hack of the campus databases which exposed not just our information, but the information of guests to our campus who were compensated for lectures and symposia, who found out about it a year and a half after it happened. One guest, an honest-to-god rocket scientist, said that she would never come back due to the University's unprofessional handling of the incident.
column50: The lack of training is abysmal. Equally abysmal is the University's one-size-fits-all approach to anything and everything digital, and anything regarding accessibility. Neither accomplish the goal of increasing access for students in need. Accessibility is NOT a compliance or policy-related matter. It is a matter of DESIGN. Forcing everything into a single model ignores the complexity of disability and accessibility considerations, and the lack of support or funding for faculty to redesign their lectures, handouts, etc. burdens professors and teaching assistants leading them to adopt the lowest common denominator solution which, inevitably, doesn't work with the next group of students to circulate through a course. Rather than imposing policy, accessibility and disability should have OFFICE OF ACCESSIBLE AND INCLUSIVE DESIGN that works with faculty across campus to generate creative, imaginative, and truly accessible content for our community.
column51: Andy Molloy and his team in the School of Architecture are rock stars. They should have their salaries doubled for the tireless work they put in to make things work as effectively as possible.
column52:
I'll repost and slightly expand my comment about accessibility and inclusive design. 

The University's one-size-fits-all approach to anything and everything digital, and anything regarding accessibility does not work and does not increase access for students in need. It checks the box of accessibility but doesn't really facilitate anything. Accessibility is NOT a compliance or policy-related matter. It is a matter of DESIGN. Forcing everything into a single model ignores the complexity of disability and accessibility considerations, and the lack of support or funding for faculty to redesign their lectures, handouts, etc. burdens professors and teaching assistants leading them to adopt the lowest common denominator solution which, inevitably, doesn't work with the next group of students to circulate through a course. Rather than imposing policy, accessibility and disability should have OFFICE OF ACCESSIBLE AND INCLUSIVE DESIGN that works with faculty across campus to generate creative, imaginative, and truly accessible content for our community. Syracuse could set a standard, and could pioneer this approach to inclusive/accessible design.

column52:
Enterprise applications being managed by academic units /departments vs being centrally resourced and managed.   

Tools like 25live for facility approval are currently managed by the registrar.  This leads to them not having much bandwidth to roll out new features and expand overall campus use.  The overhead of managing the security in that application is too much for a single user and would be better off in a properly resourced central group.  We then have a central marketing calendar, that doesn't tie to the facility resource booking (25live) at all - which creates just an additional headache and a place to update if there is a room change or last-minute update to an event. 


The same is true for any applications that are used by many but then run by a unit.   The four winds digital signage solution is administered by the ischool, which currently works fine, but doenst seem very fair.  I believe we could do a better job managing the workflow of how units promote material to digital signage campus wide.
column53:
Losing institutional knowledge by not paying market price for technologists.

Between February 2021 and November 2021 - Whitman lost 5 IT FTE with a combined 25+years of Syracuse University / Whitman School of Management institutional knowledge.   The hiring process takes WAY too long and is full of issues.   Sometimes posting the same job, with the same description would take over 4-6 weeks.  In the private sector, this is usually done a day or two after someone gives notice of resignation.   Most of these employees went on to do a similar role/job with a 50% increase in salary.   Some of these employees doubled their salaries. 

The university also has a desire to custom-build tools, which are usually great short-term on the wallet.  But they are often open-sourced tools, that require a developer or team of developers to understand and architect and maintain.   The cost is in the maintenance of these tools.  We then let the employee who architected the tools leave the university because they are not being appropriately compensated.   Then you realize when you post a job with a low salary, that no one is interested in taking a 30% cut from what they can make outside the university just to work at the university.   

The on-ramp to SU IT is very long for both reasons above.   We don't pay enough to get people to hit the ground running when they start, so you need to hire someone green and hope they have a good ability to learn via training and certifications.  We also do things in such a unique way in regards to building computers and deploying software via command line scripting tools that most candidates have never seen or done things in such a way.
column54: Everyone feels under-resourced, and they are. The only way to fix this issue is to heavily invest in the people and systems that SU uses.   Some roles require very high salaries to get projects done - that is normal.  We should try to retain good talent.  Sometimes this means we need to entertain real remote or hybrid work.   We need systems that help manage that new type of employee.

I am administrator at Project Advance, which works with around 800 adjunct instructors who teach SU classes in high schools. As many of these instructors are at schools that already use Microsoft's multi factor authentication, it creates a a real frustration for many of them to get their MFA set up for Syracuse University, as their work-issued laptops limit access and often seem at cross purposes (in terms of security priorities) with what SU is asking them to do. Even those without work issued laptops who have MS MFA on their machines find it frustrating. That coupled with a regularly-changed password create probably 75% of the tech problems we have at Project Advance, as they go to login to Myslice, PASS or Blackboard after some time and they no longer have access. I imagine these are similar issues to any unit on campus that has many people who only occasionally access our systems.

column8: The recent look and feel of MySlice has degraded as more and more applications and systems are put behind it.  It would be best to be able to have a pop-up window for each tab to remind us what is in that tab area.  Such categorization is always a problem for user design.  So, rather than go 100% into bold icons vs. detailed lists, let's try providing detailed lists behind the bold icons.  That way we can learn over time where we most often go.
column21: There is confusion out there about Google docs vs. OneDrive vs. Teams vs. Sharepoint vs. G-Drive, and all of these have differing ways to sign in, with some more successful than others.  Our Google emails with the .g.syr.edu are very problematic when someone sends us an opportunity to share a file with our regular syr.edu email, and that makes me not want to use Google systems at all.  Mobile devices are essentially taken over by SU's security, as well as the laptop I have.  I understand that, but it also does produce barriers to some activities, and I'm not sure we all know what those barriers really are.  I think there really needs to be more overview training, and a better commitment to universal sign-on with these systems.  We shouldn't have so many disparate alternatives that each seem to be requiring training to really understand how to use them.  Or, we should have the 10,000 foot up training that tells us why each is there and how to think of each, Quick-start guides and how to get more training on each, etc.
column39: I have always had great support response and the tools seem effective for what they do and for what I need them to do.  It would be helpful to have a summary of all the tools available in Blackboard and how enabling them for a class means what to both me and my class.  Some of the tools out there just seem like if you don't know what they are then you shouldn't be using them.
column50: Please help us learn how we can be better at this!  Also, when we have PDFs we have used for years as examples, what do we do now?  Some of these are older but relevant to a specific topic in the classes - what do we do if we can't actually update these materials.  I know I could search for more editable alternatives, but these searches also take time and may result in materials that are short-lived.  I think if this is important to ITS and our access-challenged community, then we really need to be more deliberate and operational about it.  Like our curriculum mapping - there should be an accessibility review, assistance, training, etc. that will help us understand more about what we must do and how to do it.
column51: The Office suite of tools generally provide good service and response, bearing in mind the need for some better overview understanding of what tools can best do what.  Outlook is pretty good as well.
column52: Remote Desktop environment is very slow and very unreliable - students complain about this constantly, and lately some of my own work has depended on this with less than positive results.  We really do need a better alternative.  In addition, the University needs to move away from such obvious concentration on residential undergrad degree programs as the primary assumption in its systems.  Everything - terms, payments, enrollment, class development/scheduling, reporting, and financial aid all seem to be great for residential undergrad in a semester schedule.  Those of us doing something else are left to scramble or take manual effort to do simple things.  We will never arrive at a destination of an "excellent" university if we don't keep up with the post-traditional world.  I sometimes get the feeling that trying to build other approaches is considered to be "impossible" or "not encouraged".  Endorse and support end-user computing, even shadow systems - teach us to be responsible and thoughtful, and then help us do our work more effectively.
column53: Multiple storage locations and "cloud" applications seem to confuse exactly where a document is and who can access it.  "Recent Files" features of tools make it confusing as to where you are looking.  Is it Teams where this file is stored or is it on Sharepoint?  Why does it seem like both, but yet each doesn't really communicate fully with the other?  Don't try to mask where things are - tell us where we are finding things or storing things.  Lately there has even been a "trying to connect" message when I'm just downloading or uploading an attachment in Outlook, and I'm left clueless as to why.  Modern computing still needs us to understand where our information is in order for us to manage it properly, and so the recent hype in the field at large about "you don't really need to know where things are stored" is a disservice to us as users.  Let's try to overcome that here at SU.
column54: Administrative tools like reporting, Tableau, analytics, dashboards, Azure Cognitive Services and RPA could dramatically assist in our work, but yet even though our students are learning these tools, we as staff and faculty are very restricted in using them for administrative purposes.  We know they are costly tools - but then don't "standardize on Tableau" and then tell me that I'm really not allowed to make much use of it because that type of function is restricted to a licensed admin (who also has too much to do to really help me).  When Word, Excel and PowerPoint came into the world's office, the goal was to democratize the tools so we could all be more productive.  I think we've done that with those, but it doesn't seem like we're keeping up with the newer tools and productivity suites.  An investment in tools for us and training to use them would go much further than trying to restrict tools to only what ITS can support, and only training ITS staff to support them.  I think we're beyond that as users at SU, but we aren't truly respected for that evolution.

column39: I can't even imagine what went into converting the entire campus to digital learning during the pandemic, and really want to thank the IT professionals who took care of it. In general, I would prefer Canvas to Blackboard as a teaching software, believe we need a dedicated Jupyter Lab environment for teaching programming in ECS, and think the ECS OIT needs to rethink the AppsAnywhere virtualization platform for many engineering software. Software virtualization is not appropriate for programming IDEs, and any software that serves as a GUI for fortran, python, R, or similar mathematical models/simulations. We need more staff available to ensure that requested teaching software is actually accessible to our students, both in the classroom and at home, as of right now it is entirely on the instructor to ensure technical compatibility. Massive turnover in IT staff during the pandemic has severely impacted research computing workflows on campus.

column52: Using open-source programming languages (R, Python, Julia) in classroom instruction. Packages installed on virtualized R and Python IDEs and on computer-installed software land in C: drive, which is wiped daily. Students cannot install certain packages on lab computers without admin privileges, ECS CIT does not have the time or resources to assist students with package installs or dependency chain issues. Students cannot install software images or environments on classroom computers (we're blocked from doing so). Most instructors I know who teach computational programming insist that students bring their own computers to class. Since software environments are operating system dependent, it can take instructors substantial time to create a packaged environment that will work on all student personal computers. Solution: College-wide JupyterHub platform with staff support (iSchool model, https://jupyter.org/hub ) or dedicated “data science” teaching lab with an alternative Anaconda installation model.
column53:
Interfacing with external networks to access computing resources and move data.We don’t have a VPN client, we use the remote desktop service provided by SU (https://rds.syr.edu/rdweb/webclient/). Connecting to external networks involves remote desktopping into a generic computer at SU and then establishing a connection to the external network (or SU research computing allocation); a process called “double jumping.” This is not user friendly: the system can experience lags, you can only view the remote resource using a web browser, copy and paste operations aren’t available. It’s making graduate students crazy.

Solutions: VPN client with two-factor authentication enabled, research computing support for students learning to use ssh/scp protocols within the SU network.
column54: WE DON'T GET RESPONSES FOR HELPDESK TICKETS. This is infuriating to me. Many tickets are never addressed or resolved. If they are resolved, we aren't always notified. I have a complex internal system for maintaining and following up on tickets in my lab group. This is not my job. Tickets need to be addressed, email notification needs to be sent when tickets are active and resolved, and OIT needs to be able to report successful ticket completion rates, otherwise there is opportunity for bias in how OIT responds to individual instructors/PIs.

column8:
My single biggest complaint is that server support is NEVER ADEQUATE for the first day of undergrad early registration nor Opening Day add/drop activity. Staff who are trying to answer questions from students/parents calling in or trying to complete tasks on deadline during registration should not have to wait through several minutes of the 'spinning wheel' while the system comes to grips with the number of users logged on simultaneously.
My second biggest complaint is that MySlice pop-ups are often incompatible with Chrome or Safari, particularly when it involves being directed to a payment site. It is not pleasant to field calls from students/parents who are angry that they cannot use their preferred browser.
My third complaint is that I find the 'tiles' redesign of MySlice to be awkward because it can take a moment to find certain functions, especially when they're located under a tile that seems counterintuitive. It would also be helpful if there were thorough staff and student MySlice tile guides published on the ITS site, because students often ask staff in my office where to find certain functions.
My last complaint may soon be moot, depending on how Tableau operates. But some of us like to spare our eyes and display MySlice screens at more than 100%. it's been irksome that display percentages have to be tweaked in order to proceed with running reports in the Oracle environment.

column8: I do not think MySlice is a substitute for personal communication. For instance, I don't like having to login to myslice to check what teaching I have been assigned for upcoming semesters and wish my department would instead inform me.  I also HATE being billed through myslice (for dependent tuition).  I want to billed directly, and I want the other responisble parties (my spouse and my student) to get a notice as well, one that says right in the email what is due, when, and why. In general, it is a barrier to have to log onto to myslice to find out simple information.  For giving grades, it is working a lot better than the old system. I believe we can also now print a roster for our classes--that is very important.  I don't fiddle with a bunch of screens while I am in my classroom.
column15: Zoom is the superior product. Also it's inexcusable that Teams does not have a filter lens.  I do not want to attend meetings where every flaw is exposed and I look 10 years older.  It's not a vanity thing, it's a professional polish and confidence issue.
column21: I have gotten to the point where I would rather buy my own laptop than work through the university's.  When I get a new computer from ITS, I lose significant usability and even worse, I have lost significant work.  When apple started offering automatic backup of Word docs to the icloud, it was a godsend to me--so easy not to manually back up-- but when I got a new computer was only saving to the HD not to icloud, paths got confused, and it lost a significant article I was writing.  I finished that article on Google Docs so as not to risk losing it, but ultimately I had to come back to Word for the editing and proofing stages. I do not like the interface with One Drive at all. I don't like sending my papers with it and getting reports about when it is opened, nor do I want to have those reports on myself.  I don't like sharing docs on it, and I don't want the headache of migrating my significant # of documents--all notes, essays, syllabi, book drafts in Word, to One Drive, I don't trust it, nor do I believe my writing belongs to the University, and I like being able to access my docs from my other devices (on which I do not use Syracuse platforms).  I like being the administrator on my phone and will not turn it over to anything Syracuse.  I have to go to great lengths now to work around One Drive on my computer and I fear to close down my computer. I also try to check mail only on the web--it feels more usable, less intrusive and more private that way.  I find IT patronizing to work with and try to avoid doing so.  The situation is already infantilizing since we have no administrative privileges over our own work tools, and then it usually only complicates my work processes to get intervention.  I would like to have more control over my programs, be recognized as the author and proprietor of my own work, and be informed about different programs and updates (rather than have the IT admin do a bunch of stuff to my computer whenever they get it that I then can't understand or fix).  If the university could step away from the clutches of Microsoft's corporatizing and overreaching embrace, perhaps looking at laptops as simply our notebooks and typewriters and libraries--leaving email, grades, and other sensitive info inside of a separate suite of more secure programs, IT and faculty alike might feel more supported in their work and goals.
column39: I keep tech use simple.  I primarily use Blackboard to dessiminate the syllabus, the readings, and to communicate assignments and updates to the class as a whole--using email/announcements.  It's quite valuable for this. But I would be happier with an attractive web site interface that didn't have all of the categories and the kind of ugly, complicated appearance of Black Board. column45: I find that the gravitation of most announcements to the website--to calendar events--has lost much of the feeling of being at a university with exciting things going on. column53: The siloed News sites are silly, a huge waste of resources, and a source of confusion. Our institute has news (posts), then Colleges have news sites, there is SU News, then someone thought "Stories" would be a good idea (they don't integrate with ANYTHING!). All of this results in duplication of stories online, and a disparate mishmash of stories, narratives, and places to find information about the SU's units. SU News should be it. Full stop. Use tags and metadata to label news articles with the appropriate unit or type of article, and then use APIs and intelligent sorting to let people display or find articles of interest (either in unit-specific websites or at SU News). This should not be difficult for a modern university!!!!

column21: I have been concerned for - years - about over-reliance on (sloppy) vendor systems to maintain adequate student and faculty PII protections vs the university having its own policy overlay mechanisms. Which would admittedly cost $ to create and maintain, but are doable. So we wouldn't e taling so much about of the university's disparate systems, but rather one common operating environoment.    The student data breach of a few years ago is just one specific instance where more than bare minimum FERPA compliance would have been a better approach imho. Now, with the feds all moving to zero trust, and a secure cloud infrastructure by 2025...maybe SU should get with the program too?  See the OMB's guidance here : https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/M-22-16.pdf which one may guess will reach universities in X years too as a requirement...why wait til then?

column52: Hello, the current accessibility requirements related to introducing new software /technology exclusively for staff/faculty use is cumbersome and unnecessary.  EVERY software/technology vendor we work with comment about the stringent requirements we ask for, requirements not asked for by any other client, including high level Universities such as Ivy League schools.  Departments do all that they can to avoid the accessibility committee due to their unreasonable requirements.   More attainable or reasonable standards would be beneficial to all and result in more departments participating voluntarily.   Or, a dedicated team that can help departments meet accessibility requirements with new technology and obtain the necessary information from the vendors, not just provide guidance, actually contact the vendors and handle same.

column45:
I have a lot of problems with the website actually. The most important one is that accessing it is extremely slow. It is probably the slowest website I have accessed in quite some time, including websites that get significantly more traffic than Syracuse. There’s no reason for it to be that slow, I have no idea why it’s that slow.

The more important problem is that it seems to be very difficult to change the information on the websites regarding my department. There’s incorrect information on the websites. Staff have contacted people to update things and it never happens. Finally I had to step in to do it myself but I still haven’t actually succeeded. There are programs listed that are no longer offered and it is extremely confusing to prospective students and I believe it hurts our recruitment. In addition the process for making changes to the website is insane. Apparently I have to copy and paste the website I want to change into a word document make the changes with track changes and then send it back. This is profoundly time consuming. And, it clearly creates problems that were not there before. For that reason sometimes we have successfully made some changes only to find that they are the wrong changes or that some new problem has been introduced it wasn’t even there before. though they seem relatively minor, these things are important. They are important to faculty and they are important to student recruitment and so they are important to the bottom line of the university.
column50: I don’t understand why it is so difficult to have accessible PDFs. either that or I really do need some instruction on this. PDFs are very important to some of my teaching.

Do computer repairs, have computer borrowing during repairs, and have a UPS or something like that.

column52:
When I request computing assistance I write consult@cas.syr.edu.  In most cases I receive an email notification that a "ticket" was opened through Orange Tracker.  There are some IT folks that *do not*  generate the email notification in Orange Tracker.  This means that I must access Orange Tracker, and then sort through many, many open tickets to locate my issue.  

My opinion is that mandatory protocol should be to make sure that Orange Tracker sends an email to the requester at every step.  I requested support many months ago, and because most IT folks generate an email through Orange Tracker, I had no idea that I needed to locate the ticket to view updates because I never received an email.  I originally thought the IT folks were ignoring me!  Eventually I sorted through Orange Tracker, which is quite an unfamiliar interface, and found my open ticket that sat idle for months.  This is problematic because funds usually have short lifetimes.  A simple solution would be to mandate that IT folks generate an email through Orange Tracker whenever an issue changes. (that's how all my other Orange Tracker interactions work)
column53: Beyond the complaint above, the IT folks are very helpful!!  I greatly appreciate all their support.

column21: How do people with disabilities navigate the hurdles balancing security concerns and accessibility?  Personally, I find it exhausting.

column4:
In 2022, why is it when you google "hotspot interference on college campus" the ONLY articles to complain about it are SU/Daily Orange... the crumbling Wi-Fi infrastructure and the lack of understanding of modern Wi-Fi networking is astounding

As a student as well as an employee, I have yet to have a class where there wasn't at least one person with Wi-Fi related issues, either connecting entirely or it is dropping from location to location. 

Then, there are 3 other networks in the residence halls that aren't around main campus? How am I supposed to know what I should be on, how to use it, etc.? 

I always personally get great support when I contact the help desk, but they can only do so much. I can't imagine they have many people to support what, 30-40k people plus all the remote people? It's obvious this university doesn't understand that technology makes this entire campus experience and product possible, maybe it should be as good as other D1 university who clearly do it better.
column8:
Lipstick on a pig. You can't just make tiles and call that an improvement to a system... 

You've gated a linktree that does nothing but link to outdated platforms that are unsupported by modern technology and browsers. You then force EVERYONE through the MySlice gate just to be frustrated with access to MySlice when really what the user needs is to go directly to Parchment for transcripts or to Answers for information or the parking or housing... those things are not "in" MySlice. The links are gatekept there. "Security" by locking a door without ACTUAL reformation is kind of sad, no?
column21:
Security theater. Doing security so we do not face a lawsuit is different from doing security because it is protective of our people and resources. SU specifically UNDER funds their departments and expect results that physically cannot come under those circumstances. 

Modern authentication is not a new concept. Randomized MAC addresses are not a new concept. Private relay is not a new concept. And yet, an incoming student has to make their devices LESS SECURE because they will not work on AOX?? Make it make sense. 

Then the exceptions allowed for members of campus because using two-factor is an inconvenience? Why are some people "above" protecting the campus just because they get six figures??? 

Look at any security policy on syracuse.edu and find me ANY CURRENT policy...  like, post 2015... go on... 

Either do actionable items to mend and improve, or just say the quiet part out loud that funding things the correct way cuts into the bottom line.
column45: Hiding articles on the web or in answer.syr.edu to avoid having to make them accessible (because why would we care if staff can use them?) is not making thing accessible
column50:
Who would teach about accessibility? SU put together a program, underfunded it, and then lost the people who valued it to other universities where they are actually valued and supported

Accessibility isn't just a pleasant thing to have or an after-thought. It is a basic human right.
column52:
Siloing. There is nothing universal about the university when it comes to its support. There is no coherent on-boarding, no continuing education for innovative technology, no governance, and NO ACCOUNTABILITY if something isn't working well. Projects and programs are stood up with no oversight and when something go awry with them six months later it is a groom of grown men saying "not it" for fixing/maintain it. 

Why is that? Money? They aren't fiscally supported? Manpower? Not enough people to do the work? This is not for workers to figure out. This is for leadership to GUIDE their teams toward a common goal
column53:
Retroactive actions over proactive methods. Unless SU is getting sued, is it important? It shouldn't work like that. We were given a gift with the pandemic. We had time to pause and truly reflect on what was working and what wasn't working in our organization. 

Instead of coming together to say: "okay, we did what we could with what we had in the past and now going forward we see that we can make improvements in these areas." SU leadership was content to keep things as close to what wasn't working in the past and continued to jam through old ideas, thoughts, and pathways.

You have an insanely talented collection of people who have worked at SU for DECADES. With this comes a wealth of knowledge. That combined with "what would it look like if things were working flawlessly" and you could come together to find proactive solutions.
column54:
Redundancy. Why do we have four platforms that can control video conferencing? How is it a smart idea to support three different data science and reporting platforms? 

Redundancy in the tech world is invaluable in some areas (like data protection/duplication) but by just turning on so many products and letting the community do whatever they want with whatever tools that choose, cripples the ability to support users. 

How do you become an expert in Teams and Zoom and Collaborate and Hangout and Kaltura all at the same time? How does SU have all this funding to pay for FOUR platforms that do the same thing? Why not choose to fully invest into one that will be expertly supported instead of many that are half-assed supported?

Departments are not encouraged to work with each other in a collaborative way with these things. If anything, they are encouraged to just stand up the product quickly so they can reactively fix whatever some higher up thinks is important to change. 

Painting over layers of wallpaper instead of eventually just getting back to drywall and doing it right, will eventually come to bite someone in the butt. Just never the right people. It comes back to bite those on the front lines trying to help.

LISTEN to your front-line people. Stop allowing people in rooms to make decisions if they are not actually interacting with the population. "Your friend's daughter that goes to Newhouse said maybe they heard we should use Zoom" is not a reason to just buy it without a review of what we have already paid for.

SU loves to play both cards. We are strong in wealth and drive while simultaneously having no money to do X or Y or Z and needing to do what we can with the resources we have. 

We are bleeding, and just keep guessing where to put the Band-Aids.

column52: I use and/or create pdf files for my classes, including lecture slides; assignments; copies of articles downloaded from the library's holdings. Making those documents accessible is a very big impact on time. I have learned how to use Adobe Acrobat Pro to make changes to the metadata of an article pdf to correct the reading order, identify headings, identify the language of the article, assign a title, etc. In a given semester, I am likely to assign 50 or more articles for a single class. The work of making those articles accessible can be substantial. Further, in some classes I am creating documents in LaTeX to include mathematical notations -- I have yet to find an easy way to make documents that contain equations into accessible documents. The work is, again, substantial.

column39: The online teaching tools have worked well for me, and I have used all of them. If SU expects researchers who use computing to reach their potential, then they need to invest in more IT support.
